p: Ensure your application uses a strong password to connect to a backend database server.
Enforcing strong passwords minimizes the risk of an attacker successfully performing a dictionary attack or guessing the credentials of an application's accounts.
Use the following steps to ensure a strong password policy is enforced in your application for database access:
Review your application's password policy. Verify that your application has a password policy. Ensure that the password policy addresses basic considerations that define a strong password:

Verify that strong passwords are enforced. If possible, check if your application's database servers implement a password policy similar to your application's password policy. Ensure that your application's password policy is enforced when creating your application's database accounts.
What constitutes a strong password varies from organization to organization; however, there are generally agreed upon minimum requirements for length and input character sets:

Define password requirements. Pick the schema that all passwords must follow. Check them for length and certain patterns. All passwords should be long (e.g. 8+ characters in length) and include a large input set (e.g. alpha-numeric and special character values).
Enforce password requirements. The password requirements should be enforced while creating and modifying accounts. Consult the database manual on setting up the appropriate password policy.

Enforce password lifetime. Determine a lifetime of a password. Once a password is expired, make sure the new password varies from the old password. Consult the database manual on how to properly set the password lifetime.

MyApp is a multi-user financial tool. Unfortunately, it does not enforce strong passwords for its database access; therefore, it is easier for an attacker to obtain the application's database credentials by guessing or conducting a dictionary attack.

MyApp is a multi-user financial tool. Because it enforces strong passwords for its database access, it is harder for an attacker to obtain the application's database credentials via guessing or through a dictionary attack.
ol:
Review your application's password policy. Verify that your application has a password policy. Ensure that the password policy addresses basic considerations that define a strong password:
      
        
          Length: The policy provides length requirements for passwords. For example, the application can require a password must be at least 10 characters long. Input Set: The policy provides requirements regarding the input set of passwords. For instance, the requirement can be that a password must contain letters, numbers, and special characters. If your organization has special restrictions for passwords, check if the policy adopts these requirements. For example, the application could require that a password must not match the user's six previous passwords. Expiration: The policy provides requirements for a password's lifetime. For example, a prequirement can be that a password will expire after 45 days. Extra Requirements: Check if the policy provides extra requirements for passwords. For instance, a password must not be trivial and easily guessed.
      
      
      
      
        
          Verify that strong passwords are enforced. If possible, check if your application's database servers implement a password policy similar to your application's password policy. Ensure that your application's password policy is enforced when creating your application's database accounts.

Define password requirements. Pick the schema that all passwords must follow. Check them for length and certain patterns. All passwords should be long (e.g. 8+ characters in length) and include a large input set (e.g. alpha-numeric and special character values). 
      
        
          Enforce password requirements. The password requirements should be enforced while creating and modifying accounts. Consult the database manual on setting up the appropriate password policy. 
        
          
            Enforce password lifetime. Determine a lifetime of a password. Once a password is expired, make sure the new password varies from the old password. Consult the database manual on how to properly set the password lifetime.

html:
What to Check For

Ensure your application uses a strong password to connect to a backend database server.

Why

Enforcing strong passwords minimizes the risk of an attacker successfully performing a dictionary attack or guessing the credentials of an application's accounts.

How to Check

Use the following steps to ensure a strong password policy is enforced in your application for database access:

  1. Review your application's password policy. Verify that your application has a password policy. Ensure that the password policy addresses basic considerations that define a strong password:

    • Length: The policy provides length requirements for passwords. For example, the application can require a password must be at least 10 characters long.
    • Input Set: The policy provides requirements regarding the input set of passwords. For instance, the requirement can be that a password must contain letters, numbers, and special characters. If your organization has special restrictions for passwords, check if the policy adopts these requirements. For example, the application could require that a password must not match the user's six previous passwords.
    • Expiration: The policy provides requirements for a password's lifetime. For example, a prequirement can be that a password will expire after 45 days.
    • Extra Requirements: Check if the policy provides extra requirements for passwords. For instance, a password must not be trivial and easily guessed.

  2. Verify that strong passwords are enforced. If possible, check if your application's database servers implement a password policy similar to your application's password policy. Ensure that your application's password policy is enforced when creating your application's database accounts.

How to Fix

What constitutes a strong password varies from organization to organization; however, there are generally agreed upon minimum requirements for length and input character sets:

  • The password must be at least 10 characters long.
  • It must contain letters, numbers, and special characters.
  • Use the following steps to enforce strong passwords:

  1. Define password requirements. Pick the schema that all passwords must follow. Check them for length and certain patterns. All passwords should be long (e.g. 8+ characters in length) and include a large input set (e.g. alpha-numeric and special character values).

  2. Enforce password requirements. The password requirements should be enforced while creating and modifying accounts. Consult the database manual on setting up the appropriate password policy.

  3. Enforce password lifetime. Determine a lifetime of a password. Once a password is expired, make sure the new password varies from the old password. Consult the database manual on how to properly set the password lifetime.

Problem Example

MyApp is a multi-user financial tool. Unfortunately, it does not enforce strong passwords for its database access; therefore, it is easier for an attacker to obtain the application's database credentials by guessing or conducting a dictionary attack.

Solution Example

MyApp is a multi-user financial tool. Because it enforces strong passwords for its database access, it is harder for an attacker to obtain the application's database credentials via guessing or through a dictionary attack.

Java Data Access Guidelines

  • Use Parameterized APIs for Data Access
  • Parameterize Dynamic SQL in Stored Procedures
  • Enforce Strong SQL Passwords
  • Use Least Privileged Accounts for Database Access
  • Allow Only Trusted Hosts to Connect to Database Server
  • Protect Connection Strings

Java Data Access Checklists

  • Parameterized APIs Are Used for Data Access
  • Dynamic SQL in Stored Procedures Is Parameterized
  • Strong SQL Passwords Are Enforced
  • Least Privileged Accounts Are Used for Database Access
  • Only Trusted Hosts Are Allowed to Connect to Database Server
  • Connection Strings Are Protected

Java Data Access Code Examples

  • Use Stored Procedures
  • Use Named Queries with Hibernate
  • Use Named Queries with Java Persistence API (JPA)
